metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with airborne PLMR mission in the Daman irrigation district (July 26, 2012)
metadata.description:
On July 26, 2012, the airborne ground synchronous observation was carried out in the plmr quadrat in the dense observation area of Daman. Plmr (polarimetric L-band multibeam radiometer) is a dual polarized (H / V) L-band microwave radiometer, with a center frequency of 1.413 GHz, a bandwidth of 24 MHz, a resolution of 1 km (relative altitude of 3 km), six beam simultaneous observations, an incidence angle of ± 7 °, ± 21.5 °, ± 38.5 °, and a sensitivity of < 1K. The flight mainly covers the middle reaches of the artificial oasis eco hydrological experimental area. The local synchronous data set can provide the basic ground data set for the development and verification of passive microwave remote sensing soil moisture inversion algorithm.            
Quadrat and sampling strategy:            
The observation area is located in the matrix of the dense observation area of Daman, and the detailed plan with an area of 3.0KM × 2.4km is selected to carry out synchronous observation on the underlying surface of oasis. The selection of the sample is mainly based on the representativeness of the surface coverage, accessibility and observation (road consumption) time, so as to obtain the comparison of brightness and temperature with plmr observation.            
Considering the resolution of plmr observation, 5 splines (east-west distribution) were collected at an interval of 450 m in the east-west direction. Each line has 31 points (north-south direction) at an interval of 100 m, and 5 hydraprobe data acquisition systems (HDAS, reference 2) were used for simultaneous measurement.            Measurement content:            
About 150 points on the quadrat were obtained, each point was observed twice, that is to say, two times were observed at each sampling point, one time was inside the film (marked as a in the data record) and one time was outside the film (marked as B in the data record). As the HDAS system uses pogo portable soil sensor, the soil temperature, soil moisture (volume moisture content), loss tangent, soil conductivity, real part and imaginary part of soil complex dielectric are observed. Because the vegetation in this area has been sampled and observed once every five days, no special vegetation synchronous sampling has been carried out on that day.            
Data:            
This data set consists of two parts: soil moisture observation and vegetation observation. The former saves data in vector file format, and the spatial location is the location of each sampling point (WGS84 + UTM 47N). Soil moisture and other measurement information are recorded in attribute file.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for synchronizing airborne and ground observations in an ecological hydrology experiment?
Example.Answer: A method used involves selecting a large sample area within a dense observation matrix, based on surface coverage representativeness and accessibility. Ground measurements are synchronized with airborne observations using a Polarimetric L-band Multibeam Radiometer (PLMR), focusing on parameters like soil moisture, soil temperature, and other soil properties using multiple sample lines and points.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of soil moisture data collected using a Polarimetric L-band Multibeam Radiometer (PLMR)?
Feature Specification.Answer: 1.413 GHz center frequency, 24 MHz bandwidth, 1 km spatial resolution, dual polarization (H/V), six beams with incident angles of ±7º, ±21.5º, ±38.5º, sensitivity less than 1K

Quantification.Question: How many sampling points are included in a typical soil moisture data collection in the specified ecological and hydrological experiment?

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting synchronous ground observation data using PLMR in the Heihe River Basin for ecological and hydrological experiments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of collecting synchronous ground observation data using PLMR in the Heihe River Basin is to provide fundamental ground datasets for the development and validation of passive microwave remote sensing algorithms for soil moisture retrieval.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed for synchronizing ground-based observations with airborne PLMR measurements to ensure accurate soil moisture assessment in ecological hydrology experiments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To synchronize ground-based observations with airborne PLMR measurements, a large sample area of 3.0 km by 2.4 km was selected within the dense observation matrix area. The selection of this sample area was based on the representativeness of surface cover, accessibility, and observation time constraints. During the synchronous observation, data was collected in the east-west direction with an interval of 450 meters, resulting in five sample lines. Each line had 31 points spaced 100 meters apart in the north-south direction. Five Hydraprobe Data Acquisition Systems (HDAS) were used simultaneously to measure soil temperature, soil moisture, loss tangent, soil conductivity, and the real and imaginary parts of soil complex permittivity. Each point was observed twice: once inside a film (marked as 'a') and once outside (marked as 'b'). The spatial location of the samples was recorded in WGS84+UTM 47N coordinates, and the measurement information was stored in attribute files.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate collection of soil moisture data using passive microwave remote sensing in ecological hydrological experiments?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the Polarimetric L-band Multibeam Radiometer (PLMR), which is a dual-polarization L-band microwave radiometer with a central frequency of 1.413 GHz and a resolution of 1 km, enables accurate collection of soil moisture data. It can simultaneously observe with six beams at different incidence angles and has a sensitivity of less than 1K. This technology provides essential ground data for the development and validation of passive microwave remote sensing soil moisture retrieval algorithms.
